issue.title: Quote text-based arguments in display names for parameterized tests

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

While discussing #4714 with @sormuras, he inquired about the `'null'` display name, which sparked an idea...

Namely, it would be quite nice to have an auto-quote feature for argument values in the display name for a `@ParameterizedClass` or `@ParameterizedTest`.

I therefore propose that we introduce a `boolean quoteText() default true` attribute (or similar) in `@ParameterizedClass` and `@ParameterizedTest` which signals to the `ParameterizedInvocationNameFormatter` that it should wrap `CharSequence` values (naturally including `String`) in double quotes (`""`) and wrap Character` values in single quotes (`''`).

Defaulting to `true` would make this an opt-out feature, but we could of course default to `false` to make it an opt-in feature.

Though, since we are introducing this in 6.0, perhaps it's better to make it an opt-out feature.

Note, however, that a `null` `CharSequence`/`Character` value would continue to be displayed as `null`, not `"null"` or `'null'`.

## Related Issues

- #4714 
- #4783 
- #4786

body:
As an alternative to displaying CR and LF as `\r` and `\n`, we could consider using `<CR>` / `<LF>` or ␍ / ␤.

The two Unicode symbols are `&#x240D` and `&#x2424`, and they are rather small.

Though... perhaps small "symbols" like that would actually work well in display names.

----

#### Options

- CR
	- `\r`
	- `<CR>`
	- ␍
- LF:
	- `\n`
	- `<LF>`
	- ␤

----

Thoughts?
I think using `\r` and `\n` is most clear. I'm wondering, though, if anyone would pass `"\\n"` and be confused. However, that applies to all options.

> I think using `\r` and `\n` is most clear.

When included within a quoted string or character, yes, I totally agree.

I've put more thought into this and #4716, and we need to decide the scope of the two issues.

----

When quoting strings and characters, I think we should attempt to align with the implementation of `java.lang.Annotation.toString()`. It's not actually specified, but basically the `toString()` representation should closely match what the user typed in the Java source code. This is probably best explained with an example.

Given this annotation declaration:

```java
@ValueSource(strings = { "", " ", "foo & \"bar\"", "\t", "\n" })
```

Calling `toString()` on an instance of that annotation yields the following (_where I have omitted all attributes except `strings`_).

```
@org.junit.jupiter.params.provider.ValueSource(strings={"", " ", "foo & \"bar\"", "\t", "\n"})
```

Thus, my goal for #4716 is to somewhat emulate that.

----

However, for _this_ issue I am tempted to increase the scope to display names in general and thus not just for parameterized classes and tests.

For Jupiter, in `DisplayNameUtils.determineDisplayName(...)` we _strip_ display names sourced from `@DisplayName`, but that does not strip internal whitespace. Thus a `\n` enclosed in non-blank text will remain in the display name.

AFAICT, we do not consistently strip leading and trailing whitespace from display names, either in Jupiter or in the Platform (but I may have overlooked something).

In any case, I think we should:

1. Consistently strip leading and trailing whitespace from all display names.
2. Consistently replace non-printable characters in all display names (after the previous stripping step).

Though my question is: should we do this only in Jupiter or within JUnit 6 in general (for example, display names for suites, etc.)?

----

Getting back to the discussion of which CR/LF representation to use...

When replacing non-printable characters in display names in general, I think it would be a bit confusing to see `\n` in the _middle_ of a display name (i.e., not within a quoted string/character).

For example, if a display name is generated by calling `toString()` on an object that includes newlines in the string representation (for whatever reason), it might be better to replace `\n` with `<LF>`.

Of if some `DisplayNameGenerator` produced newlines (even if not recommended), the same would apply.

----

> I'm wondering, though, if anyone would pass `"\\n"` and be confused. However, that applies to all options.

Indeed, if people are already escaping characters like that, it could potentially be confusing, but I don't see any way around that.

> When included within a quoted string or character, yes, I totally agree.

That's what I has in mind when answering.

> Thus, my goal for [#4716](https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/issues/4716) is to somewhat emulate that.

That looks very useful! ðŸ‘ 

> In any case, I think we should:
> 
> 1. Consistently strip leading and trailing whitespace from all display names.
> 
> 2. Consistently replace non-printable characters in all display names (after the previous stripping step).

How/where would we do that? We could do it in the `AbstractTestDescriptor` constructor but custom `TestDescriptor` implementations would still be able to use whitespace in their display names. ðŸ¤”

> > When included within a quoted string or character, yes, I totally agree.
> 
> That's what I has in mind when answering.

ðŸ‘ 

> > Thus, my goal for [#4716](https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/issues/4716) is to somewhat emulate that.
> 
> That looks very useful! ðŸ‘

Glad to hear it.

> > In any case, I think we should:
> > 
> > 1. Consistently strip leading and trailing whitespace from all display names.
> > 2. Consistently replace non-printable characters in all display names (after the previous stripping step).
> 
> How/where would we do that? We could do it in the `AbstractTestDescriptor` constructor but custom `TestDescriptor` implementations would still be able to use whitespace in their display names. ðŸ¤”

I think we could do those things consistently within Jupiter.

For the Platform in general, you're right: once the platform _receives_ a `TestDescriptor`, it's immutable.

But for `@SuiteDisplayName`, we could apply the proposed transformations.

So, perhaps the scope is simply limited to the following?

1. Display names in Jupiter
2. `@SuiteDisplayName`

rename.from: Replace non-printable characters in `@ParameterizedTest` display names
rename.to: Replace non-printable characters in display names in Jupiter and `@SuiteDisplayName`

issue.body:
while inspecting 

-https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/issues/4714

i was wondering whats all these obsolete code used for?

---

I hereby agree to the terms of the [JUnit Contributor License Agreement](https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/blob/002a0052926ddee57cf90580fa49bc37e5a72427/CONTRIBUTING.md#junit-contributor-license-agreement).

---

### Definition of Done

- [ ] There are no TODOs left in the code
- [ ] Method [preconditions](https://docs.junit.org/snapshot/api/org.junit.platform.commons/org/junit/platform/commons/util/Preconditions.html) are checked and documented in the method's Javadoc
- [ ] [Coding conventions](https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#coding-conventions) (e.g. for logging) have been followed
- [ ] Change is covered by [automated tests](https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#tests) including corner cases, errors, and exception handling
- [ ] Public API has [Javadoc](https://github.com/junit-team/junit-framework/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md#javadoc) and [`@API` annotations](https://apiguardian-team.github.io/apiguardian/docs/current/api/org/apiguardian/api/API.html)
- [ ] Change is documented in the [User Guide](https://docs.junit.org/snapshot/user-guide/) and [Release Notes](https://docs.junit.org/snapshot/user-guide/#release-notes)

issue.title: Consistently use `name = value` formatting for arguments with names in parameterized tests

type.name: Feature
type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality

repository.name: junit-framework
repository.description: âœ… The programmer-friendly testing framework for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
## Overview

As I mentioned in #4783, name-argument pairs in display names for parameterized classes and tests have different formatting/spacing depending on the use case.

When using `useHeadersInDisplayName` with `@CsvSource` or `@CsvFileSource`, they take the form `name = value`; whereas, when using the `{argumentsWithNames}` display name pattern, they take the form `name=value` (without spaces).

After discussing this within the team, we decided to consistently use the `name = value` formatting.

## Related Issues

- #4716
- #4783

body:
As you previously mentioned, @marcphilipp, (and as I just rediscovered), we can simply process display names in the `AbstractTestDescriptor(UniqueId, String, TestSource)` constructor.

Doing so automatically covers all display names in Jupiter, `@SuiteDisplayName`, and any other engines that subclass `AbstractTestDescriptor`, which should cover most common use cases.
